A request:

Please, please, please do a Critical Thinking Crash Course sometime soon.

I honestly can’t think of a more under taught yet necessary topic for living and engaging in the modern world. There are so many points of cross over with other Crash Course series (including this episode given the points raised about the nature of the ‘post-industrial economy’). What’s more, an understanding of the skills involved (understanding the difference between arguments and rhetoric, common fallacies, the structure of arguments and how to effectively communicate and engage with them etc.) and how these skills can be applied to analyze and evaluate information in the modern world of media, politics, science, economics, values (and the classroom) are necessary in modern life.

DNA was first identified in the late 1860s by Swiss Chemist Friedrich Miescher. He once tried to isolate nuclei free of cytoplasm. He subjected the purified to an alkaline extraction followed by acidification resulting the formation of a precipitate that Miescher called Nuclein (now known as DNA).His invention was followed by Phoebus Levene & Erwin Charagoff who carried out a series of researches and revealed additional details about DNA

Back in the late 50s, my parents met some students visiting the U.S. (Mill Valley) from France. We described our Thanksgiving celebration (meal) and decided to show them what it was like. Mom called a San Francisco TV station and they sent a cameraman out to record us as we showed them an American Thanksgiving spread: Turkey, sweet potatoes, homemade bread, pumpkin pie, and more. The students were especially impressed when they saw themselves on TV that evening in the human interest segment called Thanksgiving in July. They said that in France only important political leaders ever got on TV.

A minor correction to what was stated about the replication of DNA in this video (which probably was correct in a History of Science video but not in Ep. 44). Francis and Crick only postulated the semiconservative mechanism (where a template strand is used to generate the daughter strand) for DNA replication based on the structure of DNA.

This mechanism was proven in a separate experiment carried out by American researchers Mathew Meselson and Franklin Stahl in 1958. I know this may seem nit picky but the Meselson-Stahl experiment is very fascinating on its own right and is something I would encourage people to look into.
